verses.text: Hear my voice, O God, in my complaint; protect my life from the terror of the enemy.
verses.comment: The Psalmist begins with a cry for help. The phrase 'terror of the enemy' expresses a real fear for life, pointing toward a dependency on God alone, foreshadowing Christ’s own prayers in the Garden (cf. Matt. 26:39).

verses.text: Hide me from the secret plots of the wicked, from the gathering of those who do evil,
verses.comment: The idea of being ‘hidden’ recalls God’s providential protection, echoed in the saints seeking refuge in Christ and the Church (Col. 3:3).

verses.text: who sharpen their tongues like swords, and aim bitter words like arrows,
verses.comment: The metaphor of words as weapons is picked up by James (James 3:6), warning of the power of the tongue—an enduring concern in the sanctification process guided by the Spirit in the sacramental life.

verses.text: to shoot from ambush at the innocent, shooting at him suddenly and without fear.
verses.comment: Those who do evil here act in secrecy, much like those who plotted against Christ (cf. Matt. 26:4), pointing to the prophetic suffering of the righteous.

verses.text: They hold fast to their evil purpose; they talk together of laying snares. They say, 'Who will see us?'
verses.comment: The sense of impunity among the wicked is reminiscent of sinners’ presumption, yet the Church’s teaching affirms God sees into the hearts of all (cf. Rev. 2:23).

verses.text: They plot injustice, saying, 'We have devised a perfect scheme.' For the inward thought and heart of man are deep.
verses.comment: Here is recognition of the depth of human sinfulness (cf. Jer. 17:9), a truth illuminated in Christ’s call for inner purity and repentance—a journey often guided within the tradition of confession and the sacraments.

verses.text: But God will shoot them with an arrow; suddenly, they will be wounded.
verses.comment: God acts as righteous judge (Ps. 7:12–13), answering injustice in His time. This verse is a reminder of Divine justice—balanced by the mercy revealed fully in Christ’s redemptive sacrifice.

verses.text: They will be made to stumble by their tongues; all who see them will shake their heads.
verses.comment: This self-defeating consequence ('by their tongues') is echoed in Psalm 22, a Psalm fulfilled in the sufferings of Christ (Ps. 22:7; Matt. 27:39), strengthening typological links between David and Jesus.

verses.text: Then all mankind will fear, and they will declare the work of God, and consider what He has done.
verses.comment: God’s justice leads to reverent awe among humanity, an Old Testament anticipation of the universality of the Gospel and the worldwide manifestation of grace through the Church (cf. Ps. 67:7; Rom. 15:9–12).

verses.text: Let the righteous rejoice in the LORD and take refuge in Him! Let all the upright in heart give glory!
verses.comment: The psalm concludes with a call to joy and confidence in God alone. The language of 'taking refuge' and 'glory' hints at the ongoing invitation to participate in the life of God, especially in the gathered assembly—which the New Testament Church fulfills in Christ's presence in Word and Sacrament (Heb. 10:25).
